article_title: Job numbers for 2015 show San Antonio’s resilience to falling oil
article_text:
Job numbers for 2015 show San Antonio’s resilience to falling oil

Photo: Kin Man Hui /San Antonio Express-News Texas added 166,900 jobs in 2015, up 1.4 percent, according to the...

The San Antonio region’s unemployment rate dropped in December to a seasonally adjusted 3.7 percent, down from 3.8 percent in November, the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas reported Friday.

article_metadata.description: Keith Phillips, assistant vice president and senior economist for the San Antonio branch of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said the healthy job market showed San Antonio and other Texas cities’ resilience to the steep price cut for crude oil.  “Whereas last time real estate magnified the oil price shock, this time it muted it,” he said, noting that construction companies were eager to hire workers laid off from the shale plays.  Melinda Alison, regional president for the staffing firm Robert Half, said firms in San Antonio and Austin were boosting payrolls at a robust pace, particularly for white collar posts in administration, accounting, finance, information technology and creative industries.  Alison said even Houston, which had the highest unemployment rate of the state’s major metros of 4.7 percent, was seeing a spree of job openings in the health care sector.  Hiring in San Antonio was hottest in the trade, transportation and utilities sector, which added 1,200 jobs; construction, which added 300 jobs; and education and health services, with 400 new jobs, according to non-seasonally adjusted numbers from Workforce Solutions Alamo.
article_metadata.author.name: By Lynn Brezosky and David Hendricks, Staff Writers
